column1: https://github.com/ajithkvp/CSC510-SEFall23-ProjectGroup56
Item
column3: Evidence

column1: Video
column3: Video is not very elaborative, but it does give a concise overview of the project.

column1: Workload is spread over the whole team (one team member is often Xtimes more productive than the others...but nevertheless, here is a track record that everyone is contributing a lot)
column3: Commits are kind of evenly contributed, except for a few teammates.

column1: Number of commits
column3: Over 250+ by 15 people

column1: Number of commits: by different people
column3: Commits count are significantly high (and even) by 10 people; but less count of commits by the rest of the contributors.

column1: Issues reports: there are many
column3: 40 issues have been raised

column1: Issues are being closed
column3: 23 issues are closed, and 17 are open

column1: DOI badge: exists
column3: Badges exist and are functional

column1: Docs: doco generated, format not ugly
column3: Documentation is legible with excellent formatting; easy navigation and step-by-step instructions.

column1: Docs: what: point descriptions of each class/function (in isolation)
column3: Individual descriptions are decent, and the partitioning and sections of the documentation are also clear.

column1: Docs: how: for common use cases X,Y,Z mini-tutorials showing worked examples on how to do X,Y,Z
column3: All scenarios of the project are explained well with mini-tutorials (screen recordings) of working examples.

column1: Docs: why: docs tell a story, motivate the whole thing, deliver a punchline that makes you want to rush out and use the thing
column3: The project idea, the documentation's clarity, visual appeal and the future scope of this idea - all of these makes me want to use this project.

column1: Docs: short video, animated, hosted on your repo. That convinces people why they want to work on your code.
column3: The video about the repo hosted on the documentation describes in breif as to how the project works and what makes the project unique.

column1: Use of version control tools
Use of style checkers
column3: Usage of PyLint, and should abide by google style guide

column1: Use of code formatters.
Use of syntax checkers.
Use of code coverage
column3: 76% code coverage

column1: Other automated analysis tools
Test cases exist
column3: Have a good deal of testcases.

column1: Test cases are routinely executed
column3: Yes, executed

column1: The files CONTRIBUTING.md lists coding standards and lots of tips on how to extend the system without screwing things up
column3: Descriptive information in the contributing file.

column1: Issues are discussed before they are closed
column3: Issues aren't discussed with other people, instead just being closed after giving an explanation.

column1: Chat channel: exists
column3: no such chat channel

column1: Test cases: a large proportion of the issues related to handling failing cases
column3: Not much testcases seem to be covered.

column1: Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools: everyone can get to all tools and files
Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. config files in the repo, updated by lots of different people)
column3: not much info to be seen regarding this

column1: Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. tutor can ask anyone to share screen, they demonstrate the system running on their computer)
Evidence that the members of the team are working across multiple places in the code base
column3: different contributors have updated the different code bases.

column1: Short release cycles
column3: Not frequent release
